Award.AwardTitle: Symposium: Tapping the Power of Crustacean Transcriptomes to Address Grand Challenges in Comparative Biology, Portland, Oregon, January 3-7, 2016
Award.AbstractNarration:
Transcriptomic research approaches allow investigators to comprehensively analyze the profile of messenger RNA used to produce protein in cells or tissue samples. The most popular such approach, called "RNA-seq" (for RNA-sequencing) is finding its way into all areas of comparative and integrative biology, yielding insights that are difficult or impossible to attain with the traditional protein-by-protein or gene-by-gene approach. But, there are impediments to using the technology, especially for novel or so-called "non-model" organisms. This award will support a symposium, "Tapping the Power of Crustacean Transcriptomes to Address Grand Challenges in Comparative Biology," and associated activities that will be held at the Society for Comparative & Integrative Biology (SICB) meeting in Portland, Oregon Jan. 3-7, 2016. The symposium will help researchers both identify, and move past such impediments. The symposium is co-sponsored by The Crustacean Society and five SICB Divisions. In addition, the PI and symposium organizers are Executive Committee members of the Animal Genome to Phenome Research Coordination Network (AG2P RCN). The program consists of 11 presentations representing six research areas using transcriptomics to a variety of research questions in crustacean biology. There will be a complementary session with speakers selected from submitted abstracts. The accompanying luncheon, feedback booth, Twitter feed, and workshop will further broaden participation across disciplines, gender, ethnicity, and professional rank.

The activities supported by this award will include: (1) a lunch scheduled early in the meeting to introduce the AG2P RCN; (2) an RNA-seq feedback booth in the exhibition hall and Twitter feed to gather comments and identify needs from SICB members; and (3) a transcriptomics workshop to review pipelines and best practices that include responses from the feedback booth. Expected outcomes of the workshop include a policy paper on creating an interface and pipeline for the analysis of RNA-seq data, and recruitment of participants in the AG2P RCN. Conference papers planned for publication in the SICB journal, Integrative and Comparative Biology (ICB) will serve as a valuable resource for future researchers.

Institution.Name: Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: SOCIETY FOR INTEGRATIVE AND COMPARATIVE BIOLOGY

Performance_Institution.Name: Society for Integrative and Comparative Biology

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant supported a symposium, entitled "Tapping the Power of Crustacean Transcriptomes to Address Grand Challenges in Comparative Biology", and associated activities at the annual meeting of the Society for Comparative & Integrative Biology (SICB) meeting in Portland, Oregon Jan. 3-7, 2016. The symposium was co-sponsored by The Crustacean Society and five SICB Divisions. The organizers, Donald Mykles, Karen Burnett, David Durica, and Jonathon Stillman, are Executive Committee members of the Animal Genome to Phenome Research Coordination Network (AG2P RCN). This was the first symposium and workshop coordinated by the AG2P RCN. The program consisted of 11 presentations on applying RNA sequencing (RNA-Seq) technology for addressing research questions in crustacean biology. There was a complementary session with speakers selected from submitted abstracts, as well as RNA-Seq workshops and a feedback booth in the exhibition hall. 

Intellectual Merit: The NSF Genomes to Phenomes initiative seeks a mechanistic understanding of the genome to phenome continuum. Transcriptome diversity and dynamics are important determinants of how an organism responds to its environment. Transcriptomics using high-throughput next generation sequencing technologies has the potential to achieve a greater understanding of the interplay between gene expression and organismal adaptation and evolution. The number of RNA-seq studies is growing rapidly, but the infrastructure to support these studies is lagging behind. The symposium integrated a variety of subdisciplines using RNA-seq, from physiology to evolutionary biology and ecology. Expected outcomes of the workshop include a policy paper on creating an interface and pipeline for the analysis of RNA-seq data, and recruitment of participants in the AG2P RCN.

Broader Impacts: RNA-seq technology is rapidly finding its way into all areas of comparative and integrative biology, yielding insights that are difficult or impossible to attain with the traditional protein-by-protein or gene-by-gene approach. RNA-seq is being used as an experimental tool, as well as a discovery tool for generating new hypotheses. Although focussed on crustaceans, the symposium was of broad interest to comparative biologists who are using, intend to use, or might be inspired to include transcriptomics in their research. The topics represented a breadth of subdisciplines to broaden community interest and appeal, as these approaches can apply to other kinds of animals. The workshops introduced new investigators to the technology.

Outcomes: The grant used an interdisciplinary collaborative model for meaningful professional and scientific development opportunities for junior investigators and graduate student trainees. The grant supported for ten of the eleven speakers (The 11th speaker was self-funded). Seven of the 11 speakers were junior investigators (Ph.D students and postdoctoral fellows) and four were women. The complementary session had presentations by graduate and undergraduate students. In keeping with the goals of the AG2P RCN, there were both formal (e.g., workshops) and informal (e.g., meals, receptions, and socials) activities during the SICB meeting for these young investigators to network with each other and with more senior members. Twelve papers were published in Integrative and Comparative Biology, volume 56, issue 6 in 2016.


Last Modified: 02/28/2017
Modified by: Donald L Mykles
